headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Ingersoll Rand Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference,
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Ingersoll Rand Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Janet Pfeffer. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Ingersoll Rand's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. We released earnings this morning at 6:30 and the release is posted on our website. We'll be broadcasting, in addition to this phone call, thr
componenttext:
Thank you, Crystal. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Ingersoll Rand's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. We released earnings this morning at 6:30 and the release is posted on our website. We'll be broadcasting, in addition to this phone call, through our website at ingersollrand.com where you'll also find a slide presentations that we'll be using this morning. 
If you please go to Slide 2. Statements made in today's call that are not historical facts are considered forward-looking statements and are made pursuant to safe harbor provisions of federal securities law. Please see our SEC filings for a description of some of the factors that may cause actual results to vary from anticipated. We're also using non-GAAP measures in this call and they are explained in the financial tables attached to our earnings release. 
So now, to introduce the participants in this morning's call: Mike Lamach, Chairman and CEO; Sue Carter, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Joe Fimbianti, Director of Investor Relations. With that, please go to Slide 3 and I'll turn it over to Mike.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Janet. Good morning and thanks for joining us on today's call. This morning, I'll spend a few minutes recapping our full year 2015 results and our progress on the transformation we've been working on the company since 2010 then, Sue will ta
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Janet. Good morning and thanks for joining us on today's call. This morning, I'll spend a few minutes recapping our full year 2015 results and our progress on the transformation we've been working on the company since 2010 then, Sue will take you through the fourth quarter results and I'll end up with our outlook for 2016 before we open it up to your questions. 
Starting with full year 2015. It was a year that I would characterize best by one word and that word is volatility, volatility in energy markets, in foreign exchange rates, in industrial markets, in emerging markets and, of course, in the stock market. During this period of volatility, while the individual pieces might not each have ended exactly how we had forecast some 12 months ago, our headlines results were essentially right in the forecast we gave you 1 year ago. 
The 2015 forecast we gave you 1 year ago was: For 4% to 5% organic growth and we came in at 5%, our adjusted EPS forecast was a midpoint of $3.74, or actuals $3.73 and that performance was significantly more FX headwind. We had included a $0.17 earnings headwind in currency and guidance and ended up being over $0.30. Our free cash flow forecast was $950 million to $1 billion and we delivered $985 million. 
We focused on executing within our business operating system and on the things that we can control, while doing our best to anticipate the things that we couldn't control and made adjustments accordingly. 
2015 demonstrated continued progress in the implementation of our multiyear strategy for growth, operational excellence and shareholder value. We invested in core businesses, key strategic capabilities and delivered on our financial commitments, all while navigating shifts and challenges in global markets. 
We have consistently delivered on our commitments, even in volatile times and we hope that you agree that the company's coverage that have done this. I'm very proud of our team and the great people in our company that delivered another solid year. 
If I look back over a longer horizon over the last, say, 24 months, it's a similar story with the exception of a single quarter almost 5 years ago, we met or exceeded earnings commitments regardless of market conditions. 
For the year, our organic revenues, which excludes OpEx and acquisitions, were up 5%. Markets were uneven around the globe, growth in North America was in the mid-single digits, while revenues overseas, taken collectively, increased low single digits. 
Adjusted earnings per share were $3.73, a year-over-year increase of 12%. And the [indiscernible] diversified industrial peer group, we achieved top quartile performance in EPS growth again in 2015. We grew adjusted operating margins 40 basis points in 2015. Our organic operating leverage, which excludes the impact of foreign exchange and M&A, was 35% which is above our target range of 25% to 30%. And Climate margins improved 50 basis points. 
We generated $985 million of cash flow. Our capital allocation strategy remains focused on maximizing shareholder value, and it's consistent with our overall financial strategy. We continue to increase our dividend with a 16% increase in 2015 and we announced an additional 10% increase for dividend last week. 
We repurchased 4.4 million shares for $250 million in 2015 and more recently, we took advantage of some of the volatility in the stock market and accelerated our share repurchases this year, repurchasing 4.9 million shares for $250 million in January of this year. We finalized an agreement with the IRS for the years 2002 through 2011. In December, we announced agreement to sell our remaining stake in Huntmans [ph] and we expect that to close in April. Our performance in 2015 gives further conviction to our strategy and position us well as we go into a challenging global economic backdrop in 2016. 
Please go to Slide 4. We delivered steady improvements in operating margins. Shown here are the last 5 years where operating margins are up 270 basis points since 2011, despite tough years in Industrial in 2014 and 2015. During this same period, our adjusted operating leverage has averaged over 35%. 
Please go to Slide 5. This chart walks through the change in operating margin from 2014 of 10.9% to 2015, which was 11%. This chart has shown on a reported basis so it includes restructuring and [indiscernible] step-up cost, which are excluded from adjusted margins. We had 20 basis points of higher restructuring year-over-year and also had 20 basis point impact [indiscernible] step-up on acquisitions. Adjusted margins, which excludes those items, expanded 40 basis points from 11% to 11.4%. 
The 40 basis points of margin expansion was delivered from a combination of organic growth, maintaining a positive gap between pricing and material implication through value pricing and pricing analytics and productivity from strategic sourcing, implementing our Lean operating system and overhead cost discipline together outpacing other inflation. 
Foreign exchange was a drag to margin of 50 basis points. We continue to invest in new products, IT infrastructure and systems and service and sales footprint underpinned the future growth of the business and those collectively were 30 basis point investment year-over-year. 
So Now, Sue will take you through the fourth quarter and I'll come back to take you through 2016 outlook.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Please go to Slide 6. At the summary level, our organic bookings for the quarter were up 2% and organic revenues were up 3%. Residential and commercial HVAC organic revenues were each up 5-plus percent. Adjusted earnings per share for the
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Please go to Slide 6. At the summary level, our organic bookings for the quarter were up 2% and organic revenues were up 3%. Residential and commercial HVAC organic revenues were each up 5-plus percent. Adjusted earnings per share for the fourth quarter were $0.94, up 15% versus last year. Consistent with Mike's commentary for the full year, the fourth quarter was in line with our earnings guidance. A slightly lower tax rate was offset by slightly higher compensation and benefit costs. Our adjusted operating margins were up 50 basis points. Operating leverage in the quarter was excellent at 34% on an adjusted basis and 55% on an organic basis. 
Climate margins increased 70 basis points in the quarter. Adjusted Industrial margins were down 200 basis points but were only slightly down on 2% lower organic revenues when excluding the impact of currency and a rolling in the first year of Cameron's Centrifugal operating income and amortization. 
Finally, as Mike mentioned, given the impending closing of the sale of our Hussmann stake expected on April 1 and to take advantage of market volatility, we repurchased 4.9 million shares in January 2016 for $250 million. 
Please go to Slide 7. Orders for the fourth quarter of 2015 were up 1% on a reported basis and up 4%, excluding currency. Organic orders were up 2%. 
Climate orders were up 5% organically. Organic global commercial HVAC bookings were up low single digits with a high single-digit increase in North America and declines in Asia and Europe. 
Organic transport orders were up low single digits with increases in global trailer, truck and auxiliary power units, partially offset by lower marine container orders. 
Orders in the Industrial segment were down 4% on a reported basis and down 7% organically. We saw high single-digit order decline in air and industrial products and a mid-single-digit increase in Club Car. 
Please go to Slide 8. Here's a look at the revenue trends by segment and region. The top half of this chart shows revenue change for each segment. For the total company, fourth quarter revenues were up 3% versus last year on a reported basis and also up 3% on an organic basis. 
Climate revenues increased 2% on a reported basis and 5% on an organic basis. 
Organic commercial HVAC revenues were up mid-single digits with increases in all major geographic region. Residential HVAC revenues were up mid-single digits. 
Organic transport revenues were down low single digits as higher truck and trailer revenues were more than offset by lower revenues in marine and APUs. 
Industrial revenues were up 5% on a reported basis and down 2% organically. Air and industrial products organic revenues were down low single digits and Club Car was up slightly. 
The bottom chart shows revenue change on a geographic basis as reported and on an organic basis. Organic revenues were up 3% in the Americas, up 2% in EMEA and Asia was up 9% with strong growth outside of China. 
Please go to Slide 9. Operating margin on a reported basis was up 10 basis points from fourth quarter 2014 to fourth quarter of 2015. We spiked out the restructuring impact to get you to adjusted margins as well. Adjusted margins increased 50 basis points from 10.8% to 11.3%. 
Volume, mix and foreign exchange collectively reflect with 40 basis points of positive margin from volume and mix being offset by foreign exchange. Net pricing versus direct material inflation was favorable by 30 basis points driven by commodity deflation. Productivity versus other inflation was positive 80 basis points driven by strong productivity in the quarter. Year-over-year investments and other items reduced margins by 100 basis points. 
In the box, you can see that it was comprised of 20 basis points from investments, 50 basis points from higher restructuring costs and 30 basis points from acquisitions. In the gray box at the top of the page, overall leverage on an adjusted basis was 34% and if calculated on an organic basis, which excludes foreign exchange and acquisitions, was 55%. 
Now please go to Slide 10. Total fourth quarter revenues for the Climate segment were $2.5 billion, that is up 2% versus last year on a reported basis and up 5%, excluding currency. Acquisitions in Climate do not change that rounding, so organic revenue is also up 5%. 
Organic commercial HVAC fourth quarter revenues were up mid-single digits and were up in all geographic regions. North America was up mid-single digits, while EMEA and Latin America were both up low single digits. Asia was up low-teens. The growth in Asia was led by some large HVAC projects in Southeast Asia. 
Commercial HVAC equipment organic revenues were up low single digits, while HVAC parts, services and solutions revenue were up high single digits versus prior year. 
Thermo King organic revenues were down low single digits with truck, trailer revenue up high single digits with growth in both North America and Europe. Marine and APU revenues declined against difficult comparisons to the fourth quarter of last year. 
Residential HVAC revenues were up mid-single digits versus last year. 
The adjusted operating margin for Climate was 12.9% in the quarter, 70 basis points higher than fourth quarter of 2014 due to volume and productivity, partially offset by currency and other inflation. Climate's operating leverage was over 50% in the quarter. 
Now please go to Slide 11. Fourth quarter revenues for the Industrial segment were $834 million, up 5% on a reported basis but down 2% on an organic basis. 
Compression technologies and services, Power Tools, fluid management and Material Handling organic revenues were down low single digits versus last year. Organic revenues in the Americas were down high single digits, while revenues in EMEA were down low single digits and were up high single digits in Asia due to some large project deliveries. 
Club Car revenues, excluding foreign exchange, were up slightly versus prior year. 
Industrial's adjusted operating margin of 13.8% was down 200 basis points compared with last year. When excluding the impact of acquisition and currency, adjusted margins were down 20 basis points year-over-year on lower over organic revenues. 
The Engineered Centrifugal Compressor business, or ECC, which we purchased from Cameron in January of 2015, executed well and came in essentially on forecast in the fourth quarter. In 2015, revenues were impacted by weakened industrial markets however, synergies were above our acquisition model and EBITDA and cash EPS were both accretive. 
Please go to Slide 12. For the full year, working capital as a percentage of revenue was 4.2%. We had strong collections in the quarter with our DSO improving over the prior year. Going forward, we expect working capital to be in the 4% range. 
Now go to Slide 13, please. Adjusted cash flow generation was excellent at $985 million in 2015. Cash conversion as a percent of adjusted net earnings was 101% for the year. As you can see when we look at 2016, we expect adjusted free cash flow in the range of $950 million to $1 billion. That rang excludes the proceeds from the sale of our stake in Hussmann. Our balance sheet remains very strong. We have no debt maturities until 2018. 
Please go to Slide 14. Over the last 5 years, we've returned over $6 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. The employees' dynamic for capital allocation, which are just based on market conditions to put our strong free cash flow to the right use for shareholder value. Last week, we announced a 10% increase to our dividend. Our dividend increases over the last 5 years has been a 24% CAGR. Our payout ratio is in line with peers. 
We repurchased 103 million shares in the past 5 years from 2011 to 2015. As we said earlier for 2016, we anticipated some market volatility in January and we're able to accelerate our minimum share repurchase of $250 million to the beginning of the year. We repurchased 4.9 million shares in January. To remind you, our free cash flow generation is heavily weighted to the second half due t the seasonality of our businesses, namely the HVAC businesses, so our normal timing for share repurchases would have been in second half, but given we had the proceeds from the sale of our Hussmann stake coming in April, we thought it was opportunistic and still within our leverage range to accelerate the minimum repurchase and get that done earlier in the year.
For the balance of 2016, we will use the same approach as the last couple of years, applying a toggle switch between value-accretive acquisitions and share repurchases based upon relative valuations and risk-adjusted returns. We will apply our same decision-making framework to the situation at that time and leave the door open to pivot to share repurchase or M&A as it makes business sense for our shareholders. For ease of modeling purposes, you'll see that for the 2016 share count, we've applied excess cash to repurchases in the second half of 2016 as we turn cash flow positive. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Mike to take you through 2016 guidance.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Sue. Please go to Slide 15. As always our intention is to give you our view of what we're seeing in our market, sitting here today and what that translates to our revenue outlook for 2016. We've broken it down by major end markets and geogr
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Sue. Please go to Slide 15. As always our intention is to give you our view of what we're seeing in our market, sitting here today and what that translates to our revenue outlook for 2016. We've broken it down by major end markets and geographies and as you can see by the variation of colors and symbols, [indiscernible] markets seeing a wide variation in trends. 
North American commercial HVAC and residential HVAC, as well as transport and commercial HVAC markets in Europe, are generally positive while global industrial markets remained weak. Transport markets in the Americas was down -- flat to down as lower trailer volumes will be largely offset by higher auxiliary power units, small truck refrigeration and other products. 
Asia HVAC markets are expected to be flat to down and industrial markets in Asia remained under pressure. Gulf utility vehicle markets are generally flat to slightly up.
All the growth forecasts shown our on an organic basis. We're forecasting low single digit growth in commercial HVAC in total, mid-single-digit growth in residential HVAC, which essentially an all North American business for us and flat revenues in transport. 
We expect air and industrial products, which includes our compression technologies, Power Tools, Material Handling and fluid management HVUs to be down low single digits and we expect Club Car to be up low single digits. 
Please go to Slide 16. Aggregating those market backdrops, we expect our reported revenues for 2016 to be flat, up 2% versus 2015. Overall, foreign exchange will be a headwind of about 2 percentage points as we've now completed a full year of Cameron division and our results organic revenue growth and excluding FX are the same in this forecast. Translating that to the segments, we expect Climate revenues to be up 1% to 3% on a reported basis and 3% to 5%, excluding currency. 
The Industrial segment revenues were forecast to be down in the range of 2% to 4% on a reported basis and down 1% to up 1%, excluding foreign exchange. 
Industrial also has a higher proportion of revenues outside of the U.S. and Climate on an industrial experience is more impacted to FX as compared to Climate 3 points of impact versus 2 points in Climate. 
For operating margins, excluding restructuring cost adjusted margins, we expect Climate adjusted operating margins to be in the range of 13.25% to 13.75%, we expect Industrial adjusted margins to be in the range of 13% to 13.75% and for the enterprise, we expect adjusted operating margins of 11.5% to 12% and EBITDA margins of 14.2% to 14.7%. Operating leverage would be about 60% all in and about 30%, excluding currency. Margin expansion would be 10 to 60 basis points on an adjusted basis. 
Please go to Slide 17. Transitioning to earnings, reported earnings per share range is estimated to be $3.75 to $3.95. Excluding restructuring, the range is $3.80 to $4, an increase of 2% to 7% versus 2015.  As a note, for 2016, FX, as a headwind, of about 2% to revenue and $0.19 to earnings. 
For this forecast, we reflected consensus foreign exchange rate forecast. So for example, the euro, average rate for the euro is 1.03% [ph] but for the first quarter, the euro forecast rate is 1.06% [ph]. This reflects a full year tax rate of 24% to 25% and an average share count of 260 million shares for the full year. 
As Sue explained, for ease of modeling, we allocate an all excess cash share buyback and phased that to the back half of the year when we turn cash flow positive. This is not to necessarily mean that this will be the actual deployment for the cash but was down to simplify modeling. 
The EPS outlook does not include the impact of divestitures of our stake in Hussmann and we expect the transaction to close April 1 and the result in gain of approximately $400 million, which will be recorded in other income in the second quarter. We'll update our guidance in April to reflect the closing but we'll address out the gain for comparability. 
First quarter 2016 revenues are forecast to be flat to 2% on a reported basis and 3% to 5%, excluding currency. Reported first quarter earnings per share are forecast to be $0.28 to $0.33, adding back $0.05 of restructuring. Again, on an adjusted basis, the EPS range was $0.33 to $0.38. There are EPS bridges in the appendix for both the full year and the first quarter's guidance. 
For the full year 2016, we expect to generate adjusted free cash flow, which excludes restructuring cash and proceeds from Hussmann at $950 million to $1 billion. As we said earlier, we increased the dividend last week and have already completed $250 million in share repurchases, which will offset dilution from equity issuances. We had $143 million of commercial paper at year end. And after paying that down, at least about $675 million of cash for deployment that we utilize for additional share repurchase or towards M&A. 
We continue to build a pipeline of opportunities related to our core businesses and we weight those risk adjusted opportunities against buyback in terms of returns and shareholder value. 
In closing, we're pleased to deliver those solid year with top quartile performance in revenue, earnings growth. Our strategies for growth and operational excellence delivered a multiyear trend excellent operating leverage, margins and earnings improvement. And our focus is to continue to grow earnings and cash flow to further implementation of these strategies. 
We practically work to deliver productivity to make prudent investments for the future. We continue to invest in new products and service offerings, our IT infrastructure and systems as well as further developing people and our operating capabilities. We continue to execute a consistent, value-maximizing capital allocation program. So I'm proud of the progress we've made and results we've delivered and I believe we're well positioned in 2016 to again, deliver on our commitments. 
With that, Sue and I will be pleased to take your questions.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. On the first quarter dynamics, you have a decent organic growth rate but doesn't look like there's much contribution from operations on EPS. What's going on there?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. On the first quarter dynamics, you have a decent organic growth rate but doesn't look like there's much contribution from operations on EPS. What's going on there?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve, first of all, as we start to look at the first quarter bridge that you can actually see in the slides, what we're looking at is we've got restructuring cost that are in the first quarter. Our operating results are really going to be in the range
componenttext: So Steve, first of all, as we start to look at the first quarter bridge that you can actually see in the slides, what we're looking at is we've got restructuring cost that are in the first quarter. Our operating results are really going to be in the range of, and this includes the restructuring, negative $0.01 to a positive $0.04. We've got a little bit of lower share count. But when you think about what's happening in the headwinds, the first quarter is going to be part of that currency headwind that we talked about, particularly on the Industrial business. And the revenues we expect in the first quarter and margins for industrial, we expect to be even lower than where we ended the year. So in other words, we're looking at a low revenue base. We're looking at headwinds from currency. And so, I think the first quarter is just going to be tough compares and then I think we get better as we go through the remainder of the year.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So Industrial, that makes a bit of sense. On this gain you guys are going to take, Mike, given the environment is clearly gotten worse over the course of the last year, you guys are doing some degree of restructuring, but -- and you don't typically
componenttext: Okay. So Industrial, that makes a bit of sense. On this gain you guys are going to take, Mike, given the environment is clearly gotten worse over the course of the last year, you guys are doing some degree of restructuring, but -- and you don't typically do this over time like other companies, but any thoughts to may be using this gain to perhaps take a bigger swipe at things and get out in front of some restructuring that you may have planned for a couple of years into the future just to kind of solidify that ability to kind of execute and deliver like you've been over the last year? Is there a bigger restructuring out there I guess potential for that?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think Steve you can go back through '09, we've been really consistent about particularly the factory footprint and that sort of place right now where I think is very productive, it's well utilized. And when we look at ideas around us coming to 2016
componenttext: Yes. I think Steve you can go back through '09, we've been really consistent about particularly the factory footprint and that sort of place right now where I think is very productive, it's well utilized. And when we look at ideas around us coming to 2016, paybacks are in the range, say, 5 to 8 years, which is just outside of the range what we thought this environment was doable. That being said, when you look at areas of the business, particularly around compression technology, there is restructuring taking place there and largely it's the areas of headcount,  and things that we can do on a nonqualified way. So tremendous focused on both corporate and cost within each of the businesses, so there is a sort of drumbeat over time of doing but it's an effective, efficient -- incredibly effective and efficient footprint. One of the things that we find is the better we got in, that further we've gotten into that, the longer and harder is to get a payback on a closure, which is a good thing. So we remain, I think, open-minded, Steve, if, in fact, things deteriorated further, if, in fact, we saw an opportunity we certainly we'll looked at that, we'll keep an open mind on that. But rather than putting a big placeholder out there with no specifics, we wanted to just get the known actions and the announcements that we made internally, inside the company up to this point.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nigel Coe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to first of all, congratulations on great execution. Certainly, a lot better than many of your sort of high quality peers. So well done on 3Q, 4Q. I just wanted pick up on Steve's point about very clear answer on the restructuring. But I think
componenttext: Just wanted to first of all, congratulations on great execution. Certainly, a lot better than many of your sort of high quality peers. So well done on 3Q, 4Q. I just wanted pick up on Steve's point about very clear answer on the restructuring. But I think the 2 area of the pushback for '16 would be flat Industrial and maybe flat TK. So wondering if those come in weaker through the year, to what extent do you have contingency plans in place to mitigate the deleverage that you see if those did come weaker?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nigel, this is again, pick up on the point of Steve where this is where investments would be metered down. A lot of investments we're making are not only in product but in channel. And also letting attrition at times work for you, so we'll continue t
componenttext: Yes, Nigel, this is again, pick up on the point of Steve where this is where investments would be metered down. A lot of investments we're making are not only in product but in channel. And also letting attrition at times work for you, so we'll continue to work that down. We certainly have a plan to sustain a lower revenue outlook if we see. It's baked within the range we provided, a range we provided. And our focus really is on the Industrial segment and it's fundamentally on the compression technology piece. Todd's all over it. He's well into several months now into the role. I think he's got his eyes wide open around opportunity, opportunistic around what he's doing. And I've got confidence in Todd and the team that they've got the plants hardwired for lots of different scenarios at this point.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Went Okay, okay, I'll pick it up offline. And secondly, obviously, you'd be aware that there's a pretty fertile debate about on North America given the weakness in industrial complex. Does the Hussmann growth in bookings during the quarter suggest that yo
componenttext: Went Okay, okay, I'll pick it up offline. And secondly, obviously, you'd be aware that there's a pretty fertile debate about on North America given the weakness in industrial complex. Does the Hussmann growth in bookings during the quarter suggest that you're still seeing relatively fertile end markets, but maybe just pickup on where you stand and perhaps maybe comment on how [indiscernible] come out?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the surprise in the fourth quarter at least to me was the strength that we had both in applied material in North America. We had double-digit applied bookings in the fourth quarter and we had mid-teens booking in Unitary in the fourth quarte
componenttext: Well, I think the surprise in the fourth quarter at least to me was the strength that we had both in applied material in North America. We had double-digit applied bookings in the fourth quarter and we had mid-teens booking in Unitary in the fourth quarter. So as a backdrop going into the first half of the year, it feels like we've at least got enough out there for us to see in terms of visibility to see that. Also, we had really good service growth, kind of high single-digit growth in services. Controls was up nearly double digits there. So it feels like we've call it a little bit of a lift in terms of institutional markets. Commercial hasn't turned out fully that's why we're seeing good unitary, although some unitary spills through into K-12 as well, so that continuous. And then, as you expect just the investments in the service network and service footprint have been good for us. So it's a pretty good backdrop from the fourth quarter going into the first part of the year.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question around the Climate margin guidance. It looks like you're guidance for sort of 40-plus incremental margin in Climate for 2016 overall. Maybe looking at Slide 15, you might have some mix headwinds in that segment this year with resi growing
componenttext: Just a question around the Climate margin guidance. It looks like you're guidance for sort of 40-plus incremental margin in Climate for 2016 overall. Maybe looking at Slide 15, you might have some mix headwinds in that segment this year with resi growing so strongly, Thermo King and Trane Asia being flat to down. So just wondered what you're embedding for mix in Climate for the year ahead?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Julian, as we think about where Climate is going to go in 2016, I think you're right, you hit some of the high points. So we still see the continued trends in what we talked about in terms of commercial HVAC in the Americas being strong and EMEA being
componenttext: So Julian, as we think about where Climate is going to go in 2016, I think you're right, you hit some of the high points. So we still see the continued trends in what we talked about in terms of commercial HVAC in the Americas being strong and EMEA being up and on the Asia side being down a little bit. We called residential up mid-single digits. You also have the factors of Latin America as part of the business. And while you have some growth in -- those sides, you've also guide the transport revenues to being flat in 2016. So I think it's all of those mix business with could strengthen on the commercial side in North America and Europe, a little down on the Asia side. Flat transport, down on Latin America and mid single-digit growth in res.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So mix is sort of broadly neutral then, '16 versus '15, in Climate?
componenttext: Okay. So mix is sort of broadly neutral then, '16 versus '15, in Climate?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julian, residential, if you look at sort of peer group, we're right at the top of the pack in terms of profitability. I think it's a point often loss on investors is the amount of margin improvement we get ion residential business. So good residentia
componenttext: Yes, Julian, residential, if you look at sort of peer group, we're right at the top of the pack in terms of profitability. I think it's a point often loss on investors is the amount of margin improvement we get ion residential business. So good residential growth, it's good for us. It's fine. On the transport side, if you look at transport North America trailer, the industry being down 10%, our guidance embeds more of a 15% decline. We look at the APUs, we had good growth in the year, we had 16% growth in APUs over the full year. We had good growth in bookings in the fourth quarter. We've got a strategy for higher attachment rate to nonrefrigerated trailers, about a 3 to 1 ratio. If we sell 3 APUs, it's equal to one North American trailer. So there is, between APU and some of the air businesses and other businesses that we have the ability to offset that decline. And then I point you back to the European trailer was up nicely. As that moves up, that's actually given more healthful North American trailer. So net-net, we're good. Actually, what's down for us pretty big is container. We had a big year last year in container. Our container is soft. The market, in general, we're against a tough comp. But container is an area where frankly, less container is helpful on the mix. So net-net, we think we can grow margins.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick follow-up, price mix -- or sorry price material was a 30 bps tailwind for the quarter and the year in 2015. Are you assuming sort of similar-ish for the year ahead?
componenttext: And then just a quick follow-up, price mix -- or sorry price material was a 30 bps tailwind for the quarter and the year in 2015. Are you assuming sort of similar-ish for the year ahead?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are. So if -- again, you're absolutely right with -- we ended the fourth quarter with 30 basis points and full year 2015 at 30 to 40 basis points. For 2016, we're going to expect a 30 to 40 basis point range for that gap, for that spread between price
componenttext: We are. So if -- again, you're absolutely right with -- we ended the fourth quarter with 30 basis points and full year 2015 at 30 to 40 basis points. For 2016, we're going to expect a 30 to 40 basis point range for that gap, for that spread between price and direct material inflation. You do have higher material deflation number. As you recall, we had inflation in the first and second quarters of 2015. So you do get a lift out of that. But I think as we think about the push and take between price and direct material inflation, we think all in all, it's going to come back to about it that the same 30 to 40 basis points range in 2016 as what we saw. One of the other points, and you didn't ask this, but I think it's relevant when we're having the discussion about price and direct material inflation, when we think about the differences between Climate and the Industrial businesses, the largest pieces of the benefit on material deflation do go to the Climate business. There is some and there's still is a positive spread in the Industrial businesses, but it's much less than what you would see in Climate. So as you're trying to come year-over-year, you also don't have that nice a benefit coming out of commodities and the direct material deflation on the industrial side.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Russo from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Russo from Evercore ISI.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple quick questions. First, acquisition pipeline. Can you give us a little feel for where you're feeling the opportunities are presenting themselves most be it geographic end market, however, you want to address the question?
componenttext: A couple quick questions. First, acquisition pipeline. Can you give us a little feel for where you're feeling the opportunities are presenting themselves most be it geographic end market, however, you want to address the question?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, David, the strategy for us has been to look at all the SBUs, the core businesses across all markets. And so there's a pipeline that would reflect all that from that perspective. There are 2 fundamental areas that we see for investment. One is chan
componenttext: Really, David, the strategy for us has been to look at all the SBUs, the core businesses across all markets. And so there's a pipeline that would reflect all that from that perspective. There are 2 fundamental areas that we see for investment. One is channel. We continue to see opportunities, whether it's geographically outside of the U.S. channel or even in the U.S. in terms of buying back commercial distribution, that's a continued emphasis for us. We also find that when we can take a product it might be a technology that we don't have and sell through our existing channel, particularly about trade and commercial side, we do very, very well with that. So obviously, it's more attractive that if we're buying anything, it's euro-denominated or outside the U.S. and so we're pretty actively looking outside the U.S. for a lot of that, which can be than modified and brought into the U.S. with different power requirements and different efficiency ratings, but some of the technologies can be applied to. So we're seeing an active pipeline there as well.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And given the balance in power and cash flow, would you care to give us any sense of bigger than bread basket type sizing of what kind of size deals are you looking at currently?
componenttext: And given the balance in power and cash flow, would you care to give us any sense of bigger than bread basket type sizing of what kind of size deals are you looking at currently?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, probably David, truth, that would get us into trouble. I think that [indiscernible] bread basket estimate. I think that you can look at where we would and the year in terms of ratios, in terms of EBITDA to debt would end the year around the $2.4 mill
componenttext: Yes, probably David, truth, that would get us into trouble. I think that [indiscernible] bread basket estimate. I think that you can look at where we would and the year in terms of ratios, in terms of EBITDA to debt would end the year around the $2.4 million floor range. There's obviously, some capacity current debt rating, we've got the cash we talked about in the call, the $675 million, that's identified. So yes, there is an opportunity to do something a little bit larger. But what we're generally seeing are our small mid-size deals that just make great economic sense.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. A couple quick things. Tax rate, with the IRS settlement now behind us, can you give us some guidance how on you think about the tax rate be at this year, next year, I saw the tax rate guidance, I must admit I was looking for a little lower tax rate
componenttext: Okay. A couple quick things. Tax rate, with the IRS settlement now behind us, can you give us some guidance how on you think about the tax rate be at this year, next year, I saw the tax rate guidance, I must admit I was looking for a little lower tax rate in '16 given the IRS settlement but can you give us some guideline how to model the next few years?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we were probably a little conservative on the 24% to 25% effective tax rate guidance for 2016. I think that when you think about the IRS settlement, what the IRS settlement does is it takes the -- it takes the risk profile off the company and it
componenttext: Sure. So we were probably a little conservative on the 24% to 25% effective tax rate guidance for 2016. I think that when you think about the IRS settlement, what the IRS settlement does is it takes the -- it takes the risk profile off the company and it puts that all of the issues around in our company debt and any issues that would have been in the 2001, 2002, through 2011 range. But what it really doesn't do is it doesn't really affect the overall effective tax rate. So what you have to do in order to make that tax rate move is you to continue to refine your strategy. Now having all of those issues off the table, certainly does give you an opportunity and we are certainly involved in looking at that strategy in terms of the different areas that we're looking at. So we have a good trading hub that is in Europe. We're looking at Asia and Panama for trading hubs. We're looking at all of our intercompany debt and making sure that we're as balanced as we go into 2016 as we would like to be. But we do also have a slight headwind, if you will, on tax rates. And that is when you look around the globe and you think about our revenue growth in 2016, the areas that are growing the most are in North America, which does pressure the tax rate. So there's a long way around saying, we absolutely have a goal of looking at every opportunity to bring that rate down. We're still going to be just as conscientious about the items we take on as we've always been. But I do think we'll see some opportunities in 2016. We'll continue to work that strategy and continue to communicate. Like I say, it's also a good thing that we have a little pressure on that rate coming out of the North America growth.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And speaking quickly on cushions just making sure, the corporate expense, I know there's rounding and you have to give ranges on segments and so forth. But it does seem to be implying your corporate expense goes up 10% to $230 million versus $2
componenttext: All right. And speaking quickly on cushions just making sure, the corporate expense, I know there's rounding and you have to give ranges on segments and so forth. But it does seem to be implying your corporate expense goes up 10% to $230 million versus $210 million last year, is that a rounding issue? Or should we really the corporate expense is going up that much because if you back from the total EBIT, so it's implied by the segments, it is a larger number than I would've assume?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's not really rounding. But as we look at corporate expenses and -- so if you think back to 2015 when we started the year with our guidance was about $235 million, it may sound familiar, and we ended the year at $210 million on the corporate side. Wh
componenttext: So it's not really rounding. But as we look at corporate expenses and -- so if you think back to 2015 when we started the year with our guidance was about $235 million, it may sound familiar, and we ended the year at $210 million on the corporate side. When we look at 2016, we took a lot of discretionary spend out of 2015. There are some investments that we need to continue to make around our IT infrastructure, around cybersecurity. And we also have on the corporate aside. So we talked about pension in a total for Ingersoll Rand being about flat year-over-year. However, with a lot of puts and takes in element to pension, pension is a little higher on the corporate side in 2016. So it's not just rounding, it's not just putting things back in, but I'll also tell you that we're going to be very conscientious about what that spend is. And looking at not getting ahead of ourselves on any spend before we see what's going to happen in a different markets. So it's a long way of saying that the $230 million, $235 million  range is a lot more normal than $210 million but we're going to watch it closely and we're going to do everything we can to make sure the money is spent very well and to the level that we need to.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you take the run rate plus the pension, you're right, there is a little bit of a gap there, which we would normally apply to things like IT infrastructure and security that we're on a program to refresh. But look, it the markets turned down, we would j
componenttext: If you take the run rate plus the pension, you're right, there is a little bit of a gap there, which we would normally apply to things like IT infrastructure and security that we're on a program to refresh. But look, it the markets turned down, we would just look to pull back from a discretionary standpoint in other areas in corporate. So there's a little bit of flex that we would take as the markets are a little rougher than we think.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Steven Winoker with Bernstein.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, you've often talked about one of the characteristics distinguishing marks of the new Ingersoll Rand is how you hold incrementals when volumes are in the down part of the cycle. So we're obviously witnessing that inside of Industrial. Can you maybe t
componenttext: Mike, you've often talked about one of the characteristics distinguishing marks of the new Ingersoll Rand is how you hold incrementals when volumes are in the down part of the cycle. So we're obviously witnessing that inside of Industrial. Can you maybe talk about what decrementals you really think you're going to be able to achieve here if things go a little further South? And what's giving you the confidence on just I guess down low single digits in area of industrial products look likes booking are a bit worse than that and the larger environment is also a bit worse?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Steve, a great example is what happened with the air compression technology. If we take the legacy business, you run almost flat on much lower volumes. So a great example of that. That was extraordinary effort by our team to pretty pull out all t
componenttext: Yes, and Steve, a great example is what happened with the air compression technology. If we take the legacy business, you run almost flat on much lower volumes. So a great example of that. That was extraordinary effort by our team to pretty pull out all the stops on productivity and discretionary spending. And really to win in the marketplace. It's a little bit tough to compare comps against competition heavily denominated in different currencies. But we did very well there on the product and services side of the business, so that's a great example. I would say that where we try to leverage in the gross margin range of 25% and 30%. We're looking to deleverage within the gross margin range of not to exceed to 25% to 30%. So that would be sort of the essence of that. It depend a bit on the business. I mean, TK has fundamentally I think more opportunity. It doesn't leverage up nearly as high as people think. It doesn't deleverage nearly as poorly as people think largely because the distribution base of that business is independent. And so we're really turning on and off factor production, and we've got very flexible plants and labor forces that work with us on that. So a great example is TK where we would look to certainly work inside of normal margins in that business.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steven just to add on to what Mike said on the Industrial side, when I step back and think about Industrial, I kind of think about 3 big buckets that impacted that, again, no excuses, the decrementals need to be at the same level as the incrementals w
componenttext: And Steven just to add on to what Mike said on the Industrial side, when I step back and think about Industrial, I kind of think about 3 big buckets that impacted that, again, no excuses, the decrementals need to be at the same level as the incrementals when we go forward. But Industrial has an outsized impact from foreign exchange. So over a 50% of the revenues are impacted or they're non-U.S. and are impacted by foreign exchange. So you have that headwind going against them. We do have the amortization from the accounting on the acquisition Cameron, again took that on -- we took that on, but it does impact what we're looking at in 2015. And then, as I pointed out earlier when you think about they don't get the benefit or the big benefit coming out of direct material deflation with commodity prices because that's just not how that segment works, the air business gets benefit out of some of that but the other businesses within the segment do not. And so when you say you've got outsized foreign exchange, less direct material deflation and we put an acquisition in there with some additional amortization. So I think about that in the total equation, too.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up to an earlier question, you talked about price versus material deflation and range spread, but a little more on the pricing environment itself, absent material. What are you seeing in your big businesses in pricing? What kind
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up to an earlier question, you talked about price versus material deflation and range spread, but a little more on the pricing environment itself, absent material. What are you seeing in your big businesses in pricing? What kind of behavior are you seeing?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, both businesses in the fourth quarter are positive price, which is pretty outstanding, frankly, across the board. And that's with pressure in Climate in Asia and, of course, with Industrial pressure all over the world we're able to get price in that
componenttext: Well, both businesses in the fourth quarter are positive price, which is pretty outstanding, frankly, across the board. And that's with pressure in Climate in Asia and, of course, with Industrial pressure all over the world we're able to get price in that business. So we are still positive price albeit at $0.03 in the quarter. So that's, I think, a good indicator, so pricing power and sort of the pricing structure in the industry that holds pretty well through tougher times.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that same would hold for 2016 with both segments projecting positive price for 2016.
componenttext: And that same would hold for 2016 with both segments projecting positive price for 2016.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Sprague with the Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeffrey Sprague with the Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just back to Industrial for a moment, Mike. Just thinking about the margins sequentially, if Cameron hit its targets and with a sequential revenue that you just had seasonally, I would have thought the margins would have been a little been better there. C
componenttext: Just back to Industrial for a moment, Mike. Just thinking about the margins sequentially, if Cameron hit its targets and with a sequential revenue that you just had seasonally, I would have thought the margins would have been a little been better there. Can you just walk us through that? And just help reconcile us a little bit how we can get comfortable with kind of a flattish Industrial for the year coming off this Q4 order number, is there something in particular that you see in the pipeline that gives you confidence in that number?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I'll start and then let Sue finish it. I think a lot of folks who don't recognize when we talk about Industrial is impact that material handing and tools would have. Material Handling is really exclusively oil and gas for us, it's 7% of that segment
componenttext: Jeff, I'll start and then let Sue finish it. I think a lot of folks who don't recognize when we talk about Industrial is impact that material handing and tools would have. Material Handling is really exclusively oil and gas for us, it's 7% of that segment. It's been hit incredibly hard, in fact, the tools business has hit very hard by that business as well, the highest margin businesses in the portfolio. And so, when those go down, you feel it. It's a substantial headwind buried inside the segment numbers that's independent of what's happening with Cameron or compression, in general. The other thing, if you go back to compression technology specifically is we very well from margin perspective historically in Asia and in Latin America and so from a mix perspective, when those markets are down and they've been absolutely clobbered, we feel that as well from a mix perspective.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And so let's talk about, Jeff, the ECC business for just a little bit and so, I think the overarching point that we wanted to make when we were talking about that business is that it was EBITDA and EPS accretive, which is where we had hoped to go.
componenttext: Right. And so let's talk about, Jeff, the ECC business for just a little bit and so, I think the overarching point that we wanted to make when we were talking about that business is that it was EBITDA and EPS accretive, which is where we had hoped to go. However, I would say that as you look at that business from the time that we looked at the acquisition until we completed 2015, I would say that, that road map just we talked about with the entire company has a few different components. So if you think about the revenue side of that business, you certainly have the 4 components of the business with the plant air side of the business being really hit by the weakened industrial market. And so that definitely, that book in turn business, differently took a downturn in 2015. You also have tough, tough markets with oil prices and so on the processed gas side and on the engineered air side, you've got fewer projects, you've got same number of competitors. And so you've got some tough markets there and then you've got an aftermarket, which is an opportunity. Having said all of that, what we did with the business in 2015 with a top line that wasn't perhaps as strong as what we wanted is we accelerated some of the synergies in the business and in fact, overdrove the operating synergies, net revenue synergies, but the operating synergies in the business, and we're going to continue to do that. So the point wasn't that it's operating exactly as we would have called it a year ago but I think as we look to the business and with what we were going to do with that, we ended up with a pretty good result on the acquisition.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff, too, you know [indiscernible] is really strong execution here but the team integrating it. It will turn out that the synergy is going to be about 15% of Cameron's revenues. So it's double the synergies we thought we would have, which is a good
componenttext: Yes, Jeff, too, you know [indiscernible] is really strong execution here but the team integrating it. It will turn out that the synergy is going to be about 15% of Cameron's revenues. So it's double the synergies we thought we would have, which is a good thing because obviously, the top line is much weaker, and that's the reason we're still accretive from an EPS cash EPS perspective for the year.

componenttext: [indiscernible] but I think it was October and we had some settlement in December. And so back in October we said we had spent I think $233 million, $255 million the end of October, there. Did you catch that?

componenttext: Not completely, no.

componenttext: Sorry. We were talking out of response in the room and I apologize for that. So we did do the $250 million in the fourth quarter. We talked about that roughly in the third quarter call and then we had a separate 10b5-1 program that repurchased $250 million in January.

componenttext: For $250 million, quarter 1, Jeff.

componenttext: Okay, I'll follow. It's says $233 million in the Q3 10-Q, that's why I'm...

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. So what happened there, Jeff, and so you're absolutely right. At the time we released earnings for the third quarter, which would've been the third weakened of October, we had not settled out the entire $250 million, so there was a little bi
componenttext: That's right. So what happened there, Jeff, and so you're absolutely right. At the time we released earnings for the third quarter, which would've been the third weakened of October, we had not settled out the entire $250 million, so there was a little bit of leakage that was over into the remainder. But it was in October -- it was an October event. So in other words, we were announcing that we had gone into the market just like we did -- we are now. We're not talking about the first quarter, but in the first quarter, we repurchased the $250 million. We had repurchased $233 million in October and the total was $250 million for the fourth quarter.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Deane Dray from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Deane Dray from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Andrew in for Deane. So going back to residential HVAC, I was hoping you can give a little more commentary on the mix of new buying versus repair. And have you seen any change in behavior there? And I guess, any margin implications that this might
componenttext: This is Andrew in for Deane. So going back to residential HVAC, I was hoping you can give a little more commentary on the mix of new buying versus repair. And have you seen any change in behavior there? And I guess, any margin implications that this might have?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, we're seeing more -- that's not so much new construction and repairs. It's mostly new construction and replacement. And so it's moving back now toward replacement. Replacement is a very good place for us. We've got really big shares as comp
componenttext: Well, clearly, we're seeing more -- that's not so much new construction and repairs. It's mostly new construction and replacement. And so it's moving back now toward replacement. Replacement is a very good place for us. We've got really big shares as compared to new construction where shares are lower. So when the market moves toward replacement, we generally do much better and you saw that high-teens bookings in the fourth quarter. And the overall good performance that we had in 2015 where we had really excellent performance in '15.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then quick follow-up, I wondering if you can give more color on China just by segment. And then also you touched on the RF trends?
componenttext: Okay. And then quick follow-up, I wondering if you can give more color on China just by segment. And then also you touched on the RF trends?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, China, it's still rough. We're not seeing great progress in China in either business. Having said that, we're somewhat in a trough and we did see it dip further in the quarter, in quarter 4. We saw great strength outside of China, so Singapore, Thail
componenttext: Yes, China, it's still rough. We're not seeing great progress in China in either business. Having said that, we're somewhat in a trough and we did see it dip further in the quarter, in quarter 4. We saw great strength outside of China, so Singapore, Thailand, India really sort of kind of the day made for us and relative to Asia. So nice to see those markets finally recovering on that front VRF continues to do very well for us, continues to grow at or above pace of our Unitary business. And we continue to have a very high share in North America, parts of South America in the VRF business. And I think as you know, we don't play a big role outside of those territories. We play small role in China, largely in commercial VRF or in hybrid systems.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Shannon O'Callaghan from UBS.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, in terms of the acquisitions and the currency impact on Industrial this year, I think seems like every quarter, they've been almost 200 basis points and maybe Sue can provide us the split of what that was for '15, how much was the acquisition impact
componenttext: Mike, in terms of the acquisitions and the currency impact on Industrial this year, I think seems like every quarter, they've been almost 200 basis points and maybe Sue can provide us the split of what that was for '15, how much was the acquisition impact? How much was currency? And then next year, I'm assuming the acquisition kind of impact year-over-year goes away but you still have currency maybe help us how those headwinds change?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's split about 50-50 and in '15 it was about 1 point above. So translational and transactional would have been about 1 point and acquisitions would have 1 point of headwind.
componenttext: It's split about 50-50 and in '15 it was about 1 point above. So translational and transactional would have been about 1 point and acquisitions would have 1 point of headwind.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for '16?
componenttext: And for '16?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No acquisition headwind. Everything is based on calendar, it was all 2015 start and finish so there's nothing there. On the FX side, it's going to be, again, a pretty tough road to probably 4 points of headwind coming into revenues and we'd see sort of no
componenttext: No acquisition headwind. Everything is based on calendar, it was all 2015 start and finish so there's nothing there. On the FX side, it's going to be, again, a pretty tough road to probably 4 points of headwind coming into revenues and we'd see sort of normal leverage against that. So it's probably 30, 40 basis points coming at us on that front.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And your question on the full year of 2015, so the overall operating margins were down 140 basis points. And the math would work out roughly the same if you took out the foreign exchange and the acquisitions that, that would do the majority of what
componenttext: Right. And your question on the full year of 2015, so the overall operating margins were down 140 basis points. And the math would work out roughly the same if you took out the foreign exchange and the acquisitions that, that would do the majority of what the decrement was in the overall operating margin percentage.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as you think about eventually getting this business get passed a lot of the focus, obviously, currently on this call but near-term Industrial weakness, but you do have this target you want to eventually get to the '17 and '19, and now Todd
componenttext: Okay. And then as you think about eventually getting this business get passed a lot of the focus, obviously, currently on this call but near-term Industrial weakness, but you do have this target you want to eventually get to the '17 and '19, and now Todd is in place the air business. I mean, other cause a takeout to deal with the tougher current volumes, I mean, what are the key things you think you need to clear in order to get this higher-margin business a few years out?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: For Material Handling piece, Shannon, probably hit for 1.5 point maybe up to 2 points right there. So I think really an underestimation is to what the impact it would be across the segment of the Material Handling business. So add 1.5 point There. Figured
componenttext: For Material Handling piece, Shannon, probably hit for 1.5 point maybe up to 2 points right there. So I think really an underestimation is to what the impact it would be across the segment of the Material Handling business. So add 1.5 point There. Figured currency at least stops moving against us at some point and flattens out, that's going to be helpful to us. And then any kind of volume we see there, we'd be leveraging that at 30%, 35% on that front. So there's been a very solid productivity in that the business, as I mentioned, particularly as it relates to the integrated work and the back half worked once we saw the revenue outlook deteriorate for 2015. So it's not a productivity issue. It's, again, you look at a business like Material Handling, small business, that sort of an impact. You look at currency, which they get not only translation but there's a much larger transactional component there where it just doesn't make sense for us to of too many factories in machining and so on and so forth. So if you are putting in the wrong part of the world, it's hard to move those and you're going to absorb some of that headwind for a while. Listen, I think that we'll update you on Analyst Meeting. Todd will truly be on that seat and give you a point of view on that and then Robert will clearly tell kind of the other pieces of this as well, which have a material impact as [indiscernible] high margin businesses.

componenttext: I think that this has been asked a little bit already but maybe just to put a finer point on some of the earlier questions about the Industrial assumption for flat growth given the orders have been decelerating. Just maybe some color there on what's driving that expectation?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the 2009 and we saw customers abandoning equipment, shutting plants, we're not seeing that in '15, we're not likely to see in '16. You're seeing customers that are just reducing CapEx. And so you're not seeing large machines as an example
componenttext: When you look at the 2009 and we saw customers abandoning equipment, shutting plants, we're not seeing that in '15, we're not likely to see in '16. You're seeing customers that are just reducing CapEx. And so you're not seeing large machines as an example. And a large machines both Cameron and existing Ingersoll Rand, we're about 10% of the total business. Now we'll see parts and service probably in the mid- to high single-digit range next year as of these older systems need to be maintained and serviced. And we even saw that begin to materialize in the back half of '15. So again, 10% of the compression technology business being big machines, 45-ish percent being services. And then, remember you've got Club Car, the tools and the fluid business, which would be a tailwind. However, Material Handling will continue to be a headwind again going into '16 there. So net that all out and the best view we have is that that math works to about negative 1:1.

componenttext: Just a lot my question have been answered, so maybe just the first one, on the price cost spread that you laid out there, Sue, if I think about how that pertains to Climate and sort of majority in there, Am I to assume kind of normal volume leverage to that in the mid-20s, is that what you guys are essentially guiding to, or am I missing something?

componenttext: Okay. And then just follow up, I know we kind of beaten the Industrial mega trend discussion to death. But thinking about backlog, presumably coming into '16, that's a little bit lower, probably particularly low in the first quarter given that the that is more of a 4Q weighted business. Is that something that's contemplating guidance? How should we think about that as maybe a headwind to the broader leading out just comps getting easier in some of that resource industries and the service piece being an offset?

headline: Ingersoll-Rand Plc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Josh, no doubt we're going to see weaker big machine that revenues been forecast into what we're doing. Yes, what we found here in and as operator of the businesses, that the price of margins on that big stuff is not very good. It's really around the
componenttext: Yes, Josh, no doubt we're going to see weaker big machine that revenues been forecast into what we're doing. Yes, what we found here in and as operator of the businesses, that the price of margins on that big stuff is not very good. It's really around the service longevity of those systems over time as opposed to sort of the impact on sale on a quarter and in delivery. So really what we need to make up there in the weakness is service parts. And some of the smaller machines, including oil-free and segments of the market that will continue to grow like pharmaceutical, food and beverage and markets where it's more consumer-driven say than it would be through heavy industry.

And Joe and I will be around for your follow-up questions today everybody. Have a good day. Thank you.
